column4: In XP, you can ping other computers by hostname just fine. In Linux, I'm trying to ping another Linux computer on the network I cannot, yet pinging by IP works. Does Linux not support pinging by hostname or something???
in windows you are pinging by NetBIOS name, or something, so linux uses only propper DNS resolving. Computer names wont work in linux unless you run a DNS server
a quick fix would be to add the hosts you want to /etc/resolv.conf
XP uses a proprietary name resolution protocol on top of DNS, it is both slow and buggy, implementing it in linux would be a waste, Choose DNS
if you want this kind of functionality out of the box you should look at something like mDNS responder, or something alike. ZeroConf DNS or something
i believe this is what you want: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/HowToZeroconf
did you read the link i posted to you? mdns is installed by default and just needs enabling. please see if this is what you require
add a search domain in /etc/resolv.conf and see if it works
- The thing is, I keep looking at this as a global thing. If I would have more Ubuntu machines, to have to edit each one seems cumbersome. I just feel like there's an easier way to do this.
yes, set up a bloody DNS server !
- If I needed a DNS server, I'd set one up. But I'm failing to see how I need a standalone DNS server int his situation when I have a simple lan with a router.
XPs and Macs both use zeroconf, thats enabled by default, unfortunately it causes lots of broadcast traffic and other nasty stuff. If you want it you will need to enable it
if you have 2 machines you could simply edit resolv.conf on both of them...
- I understand, but I'm trying to understand the nature of the problem versus just using a quick patch to fix it. Iw ork in IT so it's important I understand how things work.
youll find that you can access your samba server via its name if you set hostname = skynet in your samba.conf
- ah hah! EXCEPT, skynet is not found in my smb.conf. Which confuses me why it works...
sometimes smb might take it from your existing hostname

- Then why wouldn't my secondary samba computer pick up that host name? I can only connect to that samba computer with an XP computer if I use the IP. If I use the secondary samba computers computer name (as I do with my primary) it doesnt work.
smb runs some sort of a WINS server on its own, or its like an SMB name resolution. This exact problem bugged me at work for months

i dont know, its iffy like that. If you want a bulletproof setup you need to set up a DNS server with a DHCP server on one of the computers, that way *all* of your machines will resolve names using your local DNS names always, even if WINS or SMB fails

- So you ran into the same issue I did? I just can't see how one samba computer works with the hostname while the other doesn't work. In both computers, I checked the smb.conf and their respective hostnames were NOT in the smb.conf, I thought maybe I would have had to put it in the smb.conf for it to work but its not in either samba config file. So I know that's not the issue.
i would advice to put them in, also im not sure if two samba servers can play nice on the network
